sections.heading: S4. Ep 2. Talking with Ralph Horne & Louise Dorignon About the Unintended Consequences of Creating a Carbon-Neutral Built Environment

sections.content: Hey, Legends! Welcome back to ***[The Building Talks Podcast](https://feeds.buzzsprout.com/1850552.rss)***! In this episode, we‚Äôre diving into a fascinating and thought-provoking topic‚ÄîPost Carbon Inclusion.

Our guests for this episode are ***[Ralph Horne](https://www.linkedin.com/in/ralph-horne-b881049/)*** and ***[Louise Dorignon](https://www.linkedin.com/in/louise-dorignon/)*** from ***[RMIT University](https://www.rmit.edu.au/)*** in Melbourne. Ralph is the Associate Deputy Vice Chancellor at the College of Design and Social Context, while Louise serves as the Vice Chancellor‚Äôs Postdoctoral Research Fellow. Together, along with others they‚Äôve co-authored *Post Carbon Inclusion* (~[get your hands on a copy here](https://www.amazon.com.au/Post-Carbon-Inclusion-Transitions-Built-Justice/dp/152922943X/)~), a book that explores the intersection of decarbonisation and inequality within the built environment.
This episode goes beyond the usual discussions around project delivery, companies, design, engineering or architecture. Instead, we ask big-picture questions:

items: How do we ensure decarbonisation is delivered equitably? üåè
What are the unintended consequences of creating a carbon-neutral built environment? üöß
How do renewable energy initiatives and housing solutions factor into the broader social impact of decarbonisation? üè°
Understanding the unintended consequences of decarbonisation within the built environment
Urban experiments often reveal hidden challenges and unintended impacts
Inclusivity is critical for sustainable urban planning and housing solutions
Housing should be viewed as essential social infrastructure, not just a commodity
Australia has room to improve housing standards compared to global leaders
Collaboration and understanding local contexts are vital for successful sustainability initiatives
